•… ed womē / or •… che virgyns •… don purpose •… be maryed. But our lord god doth more hede and wey the entent & mȳde / than ye wordes or speche. And therfore ye amendes is ye sooner made / where the entent is pure wtout ony malyce. The lettre. Nō autē carnalis / sed spūalis debet esse īter vos dilectio. That is. But amonge you may be no carnall loue / but all spirytuall. Parcialite is neuer good amonge relygyous {per}sones / specyally in ye souerayne / as to fauour one persone more than an other / bycause of kynne / coūtree / or acqueyntaunce: nor yet for bodyly seruyce & pleasure. But ye fauour of religyous {per}sones sholde all be grounded in vertue / & for vertu / more to loue is lawful. The carnall loue (all though it be naturall) sholde in {per}fyte religyon be clene forgoten. So done we rede in ye lyues of the olde faders / yt many {per}sones wold neyther se nor here / nor in ony wyse meddle wt theyr owne parentes ne kynne. For carnall frendes done moche hyndre the {per}feccyon of good religyon / & oft done cause grete murmure & grudge amonge the company. But se now

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ Many {per}sones done loue well theyr felowes / but yt is for affeccyon of kynrede / or carnall acqueyntaunce. And all though suche loue be not agaynst holy scripture / yet is it of lytell {per}feccyon. For grete difference is bytwene the meryte of yt thynge we do of our owne good wyll after ye disposicyon of nature / & that we do of charite by ye cōmaūdement of our lord for obedience. For ye one is spirytuall / & the other carnall. And ye spirytuall loue yt is charite / doth proue ye religyous {per}sones to be the seruaūtes of god. He sayd hȳselfe. In this thynge onely may all men knowe yt you be my disciples / yf ye eche loue other. Whiche loue (yf it be holy in ye herte)
wyll appere by these two thynges / yt is to saye / yf we loue our frēdes in god / & our foos or enemyes for god. But many ben deceyued in ye loue of theyr enemyes / sayenge & supposynge they loue them well ynough / but the very profe therof is / whan we ben no thynge grudged ne greued with the welthe & profyte of our enemyes / nor ony thynge gladde to here of theyr hynderaūce. Charite dothe begyn at two groundes / two preceptes. The loue of god / and the loue of the neyghbour / but this charite dothe appere & shewe it selfe in thynges innumerable / & dothe extende vnto infynyt •… goodnes. The loue of god is cōmaunded to be ha • in thre maners / of all the herte / all the mynde / & all fortytude and myght. So that who loueth god perfytly / and so wolde please hym / they leue no thynge vnto themselfe / but all they done gyue frely vnto hym. And the loue of the neyghboure standeth in two preceptes of the two testamentes. The fyrst is.Tobi. iii •…
That ye wolde not were done vnto you / do not you vnto ony other. The seconde is of the gospell.Mat. vij. Que vultis vt faciant vobis homines. &c. what ye wolde other persones sholde do vnto you / do you the same vnto them. By the fyrst all malyce and euyll wyll is restrayned. For whan a {per}sone wyll not do / that he wolde not suffre / he wyll no thynge noye ne hurte his neyghbour. And by the seconde all benignite and kyndnes is nourysshed. For whan he dothe that he wolde were done vnto hym / by that kyndnes he shall {pro}fyte his neyghbour / and multiply charite. And so in leuynge that he sholde not do / & in doynge that he sholde do / he moche encreaceth all maner of vertue. For in auoydyng that he wolde not were done vnto hym / he hath hymselfe
in a good awayte that his countenaūce or behauyour be not to hygh vnto the occasyon of his neyghboure: nor that he neyther moue / ne lyghtly be moued vnto ony displeasure / ne say or here ony euyll of his neyghbour / ne ony thynge speke contrary vnto good maner and edyfycacyon of vertue. Ne ony tyme desyre his neyghbours goodes / wyfe / doughter / or seruaunt: ne yet be negligent in ony thynge that louynge kyndnes requireth to be done. And on the other behalfe / whan a persone studyeth to do that good & {pro}fyte vnto other persones / that he wold were done vnto hym / than is he euer besy to do good for euyll / and for kyndnes to shewe more kyndnes / to edyfye all vertue / and to destroy all vyce / and so euer in correccyon to be moderate and discrete / that ye subiectes be neuer remoued from iustyce. And euer to lay all parcialite on parte / yt none be notably fauoured before an other / excepte they be knowen of more notable vertue: ne ony more straytly delte wt than an other / excepte they be knowen more than other mysordred. And yf the souerayne can not lyghtly refourme the defaute / yet make it not open yf it be preuy. And yf it be open & knowen / so rebuke or correcte it / that the sylence or want of iustyce shold not seme to consent vnto the synne. And in all that they do let them beware of pryde / do no thynge for the laude & prayse of the worlde / but all for ye loue & honour of god So may ye se & perceyue that charite is in many maners.j. Co. xiij. Saynt Paule. Charitas benigna est. &c. Charite is very gentyll / benygne / mercyfull / & pyteous / & charite wyll do no wronge.a. l. Honore seruato: ne illo offendatur de{us}. multo magis. &c. The lettre. Preposito / tan{quam} patri obediatur. multo magis presbitero / qi oīnt vestrū curā gerit. That is. Let due obedience be gyuē
vnto the souerayne / as vnto the fader or moder: moche more vnto the ghostly fader / ordynary / or bysshop that of you all hath ferther charge. Here is ye expresse cōmaundement of obedyence / the thyrde essencyall of the rule / and moost princypall lady and maystres / vnto whome (as ofte we haue sayd) all the other ben ordred. This latyn (prepositus) we done englysshe and put for the souerayne / whiche terme may well be taken for a presydent / as pryour / subpryour. &c. vnder an abbot. And the terme presbiter / may be taken for the heed or souerayn / vnto whome obedience is made as abbot / pryour: abbesse / pryouresse. For vnto them after ordre & degre / for tyme and place / all the couent must be obedyent. Yf than we sholde obey our presydentes as our fader and moder / what obedience shold we than haue vnto our souerayn? Truly moche more so moche more as the souerayne vseth the place / rome & persone of our sauyour. Ergo our souerayne is ferre aboue our naturall and carnall parentes / ye as ferre (I saye) as the soule is aboue the body / & the spiryte aboue the flesshe.Exo. xx. But we ben bounden by the lawe of god / to be obedyent vnto our carnall parentes / and yf we sholde be rebellyous agaynst them / we sholde suffre deth.Exo. xxj. Ergo moche more ben we boūde vnto our spirytuall soueraynes.Num̄. xij And that is playnly shewed by Mary the syster of Aaron / that for grudgynge & murmurynge agaynst her souerayne Moyses / was made lepre / & so remayned as acursed from all the company certayne dayes / vnto the tyme yt by the prayers of her sayd souerayne / her synne was forgyuen / & she made hole. It is good therfore that all religyous persones be well ware how they murmure or grudge agaynst
theyr soueraynes / for drede of the vengeaunce of god. Of this lady dame obedyence we haue wryten vnto you more largely in ye fyrst boke of ye essencyall vowes Ye shall now therfore here your

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ Obedyence alone is the vertue that graffeth & engendreth all other vertues in the mynde and herte of man.j. Re. xv. So obedience (as scripture sayth) is better than sacrefyce or oblacyon. For by sacrefyce / is offred the flesshe or body of beestes. But by obedience is the selfe persone hooly bothe in soule & body offred. Salomon sayth.Prou. xxj. Vir obediēs loquitur victorias. The obedient persones may speke of grete victory. For where they subdue themselfe vnto the cōmaundement of an other persone / in that done they vaynquysshe themselfe and wynne the victory in theyr hertes. For the cōmaūdement of obedyence is gyuen vnto religyous persones not for a daye or a yere / but vnto deth. And all though the religyous {per}sone sholde neuer by obedience do euyll yet may a good dede somtyme be lefte or dyfferred by obedyence / or for obedyence. Somtyme tho thynges ben cōmaunded by obedyence that ben of pleasure / as honour / offyce / dignite / or degre: and than yf the appetyte and wyll of ye persone do enclyne thervnto / the obedyence is as no thynge / of very lytell meryte. And somtyme tho thynges ben cōmaunded that ben greuous and dyspleasaunt / and than yf the wyll & desyre of the persone be not thervnto / the meryte is also very lytell. Therfore the very true obedyence must in all thynges of pleasure haue no wyll ne desyre of the persone. And contrary / in all thynges greuous & penitencyall / it must haue good wyll & consent / so the glory & prayse of obedyence standeth in that it is alwaye coupled
& knytte vnto the wyll and ordynaūce of an other persone. And the beauty of obedyence is the innocency of the mynde / whan a {per}sone as a beest wyll do what they ben cōmaunded or set vnto. Our lorde doth assymyle ye obedient persone vnto a shepe / sayenge.Ioan. x. Oues mee / vocē meā audient. &c. My shepe (sayth he) wyll here my voyce / and I knowe them / and they wyll folowe me & kepe my cōmaundement. Without doubte the persone that is not innocent / shall neuer truly be obedyent. And who so is not obedyent / is neuer innocent. They must euer be coupled togyder. The lettre. Vt autē cūcta ista seruentur / precipimus: vt si quid seruatum minus fuerit: non negligenter pretereatur: sed vt emendandū corrigendū{que} / a preposito curetur. Ad prepositum precipue pertinebit / vt ad presbiterū: cuius est maior auctoritas / referat: quod modum vel vires eius excedit. That is. We therfore done straytly cōmaūde and charge you / that all these premysses be obserued and kepte: so that yf ony artycle or poynt be not hooly kepte / it be not neglygently ouerpassed / ne dissymuled / but that for ye reformacyon / amendement and correccyon of the same / cure and hede be gyuen of the souerayne. For vnto the soueraynes shall appertayn / that yf ony thynge passe or excede theyr wyttes or power / they shewe it playnly vnto the preest / ordynary / or visytour / that hath the more large auctorite. This lettre dothe moche charge the hedes and soueraynes / to gyue dylygence and to se that this rule be kepte. And also yf ony poynt be broken therof and not kepte / they do due correccyon for ye reformacyon therof. Alas where ben ye soueraynes of this rule? where done they dwell? In the graunges I suppose / or in
theyr gaye maner places. For in the cloyster is no rule kepte / and in some couentes they haue no rule / except it be closed vp vnder locke and key / for some professed persones dyd neuer se nor here tell of ony rule / and so as they professed they wote not what / so they kepe it they wote not how. But (I tell you) the hedes & soueraynes shall make strayte accoūt therof / & paye therfore euery peny. For vnto them belongeth to se ye rule kepte / and to do correccyon for the transgressyon and brekynge therof. And therfore the subiectes sholde not thynke the soueraynes cruell nor harde herted / whan they done correct. For (as ye here may se) they ben boūden thervnto / vnto the vttermest of theyr power. And yet ferthermore / yf it passe theyr power / they be not so excused / but they ferther complayne vnto theyr superyours. And this poynt of the rule in many places / is moche ouerpassed / & lytell heded. For yf a subiecte be vpholden / and borne out by seculer kynne or frendes / and so be (in maner vncorrygyble and vnreformable) the soueraynes / rather than they wyll dysplease the seculer persones / wyll dyssymule the defautes of the subiectes / and suffre them to do what they wyll / and neyther wyll they correcte ne complayne / where (as I sayd) they ben bounde vnto bothe / as the cause is gyuen / but euer in due maner / with pyte and compassyon / not as a lorde and mayster / but rather as a pyteous and moost charytable parent / a fader or moder / and that foloweth. But fyrst here

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ The preceptes and cōmaundementes of this holy rule were gyuen and ordeyned to be kept in dede / and not to be onely redde or herde: how be it they must also
bothe be redde and herde. And yf ony poynt be ouer passed and not kepte / it must shortly be refourmed and amended. For ye soueraynes may not negligently ouer passe ony poynt without peryll and ieoperdy of soule / and the subiectes haue by vowe professed and sworne to kepe all. The psalmist sayth.{pre}s. cxvi Tu mandasti mandata tua custodiri nimis. Good lorde thou hast cōmaūded all thy cōmaūdementes to be straytly kepte. And the apostle sayth.Iaco. ij. Yf a persone kepe all the hole lawe / and offende but in one poynt alone / he is culpable and gylty of all the hole lawe. Therfore it dothe appertayne vnto the presydentes as kepers of the ordre and religyon / to shewe vnto the soueraynes: and vnto the soueraynes appertayneth to shewe vnto the ordynary all maner of doubtes / that by the expresse rule be not determyned. For ye prelates ben ordeyned in Chrystes chirche to conserue and kepe the well ordred statutes / and to refourme that is amysse / and specyally that by the example of theyr wordes and werkes the lyfe and good maners of the subiectes sholde be edyfyed vnto good religyon and vertue / after ye doctryne of saynt Paule / sayenge vnto his disciple.ij. Ti. ii Argue / obsecra / increpa. &c. Reproue thou (sayth he) and praye thou or entreate / and blame some other persones. All he ment for the tyme and place / and as the mater requireth & the state of the persone: now to speke sharply / & an other tyme gentylly. Reproue ye rude / wylde / and vnrestfull {per}sones. And curteysly entreate ye meke obedyent & pacyent persones. And the proude / neglygent & slouthfull persones shold the souerayne eyther blame or correcte forthwith / and neuer dyssymule the defautes of the subiectes / lest they fall in the daunger
of god / as dyd Hely the preest of the olde lawe.j. Re. ij. They must therfore warne the honest & lerned / or wyse persones / ones or twyse before ony open correccyon / and the cōmune dayly trespacers yt ben proude / frowarde disobedient / and that lytel done fere or drede to offende god & the statutes / they must be shortly & sharply correcte with discyplynes / fastynges / and (yf it nede) by imprysonment.Pro. xix. For ye wyse man sayth. A fole or a frowarde persone / is not corrected by wordes. And in an other place.Pro. xxiij Correcte and bete thy childe with a rodde and so thou shalte delyuer his soule from dethe. The lettre. Ille autē qui vobis preest: non se existimet potestate domināte / sed charitate seruiente / felicē. That is. And as vnto your soueraynes that ben aboue you all / let not them thynke themselfe happy or well at ease for the power and auctorite of theyr dominacyon and hygh rome / but rather for the charite / good wyll and desyre they haue (in our lorde) to be as mynistres and to do seruyce. Here appereth that I sayd before / the soueraynes sholde not thynke themselfe lordes or maysters ouer theyr subiectes / but rather as faders or moders.Math̄. xx For (as our sauyour sayd) Prīcipes gentium dominantur co{rum}. That is. the maner and behauyour of worldly prynces and potestates is that they ben extolled and enhaūced in pryde by theyr power & dominacyons: but amonge religyous {per}sones it may not be so. But rather the soueraynes there and superyours must be as mynystres and seruauntes. It is an olde sayenge. Vinum et magistratus / ostendunt hominem. Good drynke and hygh rome / wyll soone shewe what the persone is. For the brayne and wytte of many persones done seme very good tyll they come
vnto the stronge wyne or good ale / and than ben they soone gone. And the maners of many persones done seme full sobre whyle they be vnder: but yf they come ones aboue / than they shewe themselfe. Take hede now vnto your holy

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ The soueraynes that ben gladde & ioyfull of theyr power and hygh rome / ben not very soueraynes / but rather (as our sauyour sayd) mercennaryes and waged seruauntes / yt haue more appetyte to haue hygh place & pleasure / than to edyfye and profyte the chirche of Chryst:Ioan. x. they coueyte more to haue temporall lucre / than the helth of soules: and more to haue temporall honour / than eterne and euerlastynge glory. And therfore (as our sauyour sayd) Receperūt mercedē suam. They receyue here theyr rewarde.Mat. vj. But the prelates that ben gladde and Ioyfull to mynystre and do seruyce for charite / those ben very prelates / and those done theyr offyce after the lawe and wyll of god. For they done folowe the doctryne of our sauyour / that came rather to do seruyce / than to take seruyce.Math̄. xj And they done labour with all dylygence to brynge many soules vnto our lorde: moche more glad to take charge and labour / than honour and pleasure. Charite pleaseth them / and not the rome ne power / and with better wyll done they serue other persones / than take of them ony seruyce. So saynt Paule techeth / sayenge. Whan I was at free lyberty / I made my selfe a bonde seruaunt vnto all persones / that I myght wynne many.j. Co. ix. And yet notwithstandynge he was had in due honour and reuerence of his subiectes / and so sholde the good prelate be had of his subiectes / & so foloweth in the lettre. Honore coram vobis / prelatus sit vobis.a. l. coram hominib{us}
That is. Let your soueraynes. in all due honour and reuerence be your prelates and aboue you all. Here ye may perceyue that by expresse commaundement the discyples of this rule ben boūden to do reuerence and honour vnto theyr soueraynes: and so must than folowe that they ben also boūden to loue theyr soueraynes. For as loue without honour is chyldysshe & doth appertayne vnto chyldren / so is honour without loue mockery / and dothe appertayne vnto mockers & scorners. Herken now

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p: ¶ The soueraynes must haue due honour / bycause they in the monastery done vse the rome and persone of our sauyour Iesu.Luce. x. So he sayd hymselfe. Who so hereth you and dothe obey you / dothe here & obeyeth me. And who so despyseth & is vnto you disobedyent / dothe despyse and is inobedyent vnto me. The true seruauntes of god wyll therfore honour in theyr prelates / theyr lorde and mayster Iesu. For whose loue they toke them to be theyr maysters and soueraynes / whiche prelates sholde notwithstandynge haue euer vnto our lorde a reuerent drede. And the more they be honoured outwarde / the more sholde they inwarde thynke themselfe vnworthy & moost vyle of all other. so foloweth in the lettre.a. l. non hʐ habet timore. sz corā deo. Timore coram deo / sit substratus pedibus vestris. That is. But in reuerent drede before our lorde / let them lye prostrate before your fete. That texte let them lye / is not referred vnto the subiectes / that they shold loke for ony honour of theyr soueraynes / but it is spoken vnto ye soueraynes / that they sholde (as is sayd) thynke them selfe moost vnworthy / and no thynge to preferre them selfe in theyr owne opynyon before god / for theyr rome & offyce.

div.head: ¶ Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ Sapyence saythe. Eccli. iij. The more thou arte in reputacyon / the more sholdest thou meke thy selfe. And in an other place. Ecc. xxxi •…
The people haue made the theyr heed & souerayne / be thou no thynge proude therof / but be amonge them as one of them. Luc. xiiij And our lord in the gospell. Who so dothe humble and make lowe themselfe shall be exalted. And who so wyll exalte and enhaūce themselfe / shall be brought downe full lowe. For the more lowe a {per}sone be in his owne opynyon / the more hygh is he before god. Now foloweth what condycyons the soueraynes sholde haue. The lettre. Circa omnes / seipsum bonorum operum: prebeat exemplum. That is. Let the soueraynes vnto the edifycacyon of all persones / make them selfe example of all good werkes. The example of the souerayne / is the best lesson vnto the subiectes. Act. j. Our sauyour hymselfe (saythe saynt Luke) I began fyrste to werke and do well / and after to teche and preche. The good housbonde saythe vnto his seruaūtes: come and let vs go vnto the felde. And the euyll housbonde saythe vnto his seruauntes: go you vnto the felde / and he is serued therafter. Aristotel. in econo. ¶ There was a persone axed a good housbonde / what thynge wolde make an horse fatte & fayre. And he answered / sayenge. The eye or syght of his mayster. ¶ An other axed what wolde make a fatte muckhepe / or a good dunghyll. And he sayd. The steppe of the good housbonde. The soueraynes of this rule ben bounde to go before / and fyrst kepynge the rule themselfe / bydde theyr subiectes and cōmaunde them to folowe. But this marreth all relygyon / whan the soueraynes bydde them go / and they wyll
not go forth them selfe before. Whan they bydde the subiectes do this / do that / and they no thynge wyl do them selfe. They wyll take more lyberty than they wyll gyue. Our sauyoure complayned vpon them / sayenge.Mat. xxz. They wyll put vnto ye people greuous charges / but they wyll not put to a fynger / they wyll not do the leest labour / to shewe the example in theyr dedes. They sholde (sayth the lettre) make them selfe example of all good werkes.Texte. And that: circa omnes. that is / for the charge / and vnto the cure and edifycacyon of all the subiectes. By that (me semeth) that the souerayne sholde folowe the maner of saynt Paule / that sayd of hymselfe.j. Co. ix. Factus sum iudeis / tan{quam} iudeus. hijs qui sub lege sunt / quasi sub lege essem. hijs qui sine lege erant. &c. I ordred my selfe (sayth he) vnto ye iewes as a iewe / to wynne them vnto them that were bounde vnto the lawe / as though I hadde ben bounde thervnto. And vnto them that were without lawe / as though I had ben lawles. I also ordred my selfe vnto feble persones / as a feble persone. And shortly to cōclude / I made and ordred my selfe vnto all persones / in all thynges after theyr behauyour & dysposycyon / to the entent to wynne them vnto Chryst. So sholde all hedes and prelates do vnto theyr subiectes in all pacyence and louynge maner / not folowynge ne fauourynge them in ony synne or mysbehauyour. For that dyd not saynt Paule / but al to wynne them from vyce / or to edyfye them in vertue. Take hede vnto

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ As the soueraynes done precede and go before the subiectes in ordre and degree / so sholde they precede & go before them in sanctite and holynes / that by theyr
example of lyuynge / the subiectes sholde lerne how to lyue. The lettre.Texte. Corripiat inquietos / consoletur pusillanimes / suscipiat infirmos / patiens sit ad omnes. That is. Let the soueraynes blame and correcte the vnrestfull and besy persones. And the feynt herted / scrupulous and ferefull persones / let them conforte & make bolde. The infyrme / frayle / and inconstaūt persones / they must bere with pyte and compassion / and take them vnto mercy. And they must be pacyent vnto all persones.Nota. ¶ A notable doctryne vnto the soueraynes / or rather a commaundement / foure synguler lessons. The fyrst / that they do correccyon: but vnto whome? vnto the vnrestfull. For they be enemyes vnto the fyrst precepte of the rule / that was / that they sholde be restfull / peacefull / of one mynde and wyll / of one herte and loue in our lorde. The soueraynes that done rule more of charite than of power / & that done gyue the good example of theyr werkes / may well & reasonably do correccyon. For they ben the very soueraynes of this rule: so the lettre sheweth nexte before this lesson. The seconde lesson. Let them conforte the feynt & scrupulous persones. The persones that done offende and make many defautes worthy correccyon / yet whan they so do / not of wyll / but by fere of conscyence / and by a scrupulous mynde / they had more nede of cōsolacyon / than of eyther rebuke or correccyon For that selfe passyon / is vnto them more paynfull than ony correccyō. The soueraynes therfore must by wyse counseyle & confortable maner study to strength them / to make them bolde agaynst all suche doubtfull dredes. And this is the seconde lesson of dyscrecyon. The thyrde lesson. Suscipiat infirmos. That is. Let
the soueraynes also take ye frayle persones vnto mercy. This lettre is translated in some bokes that the soueraynes sholde take ye seke persones vnto theyr cure and charge / meanynge ye bodyly conforte of suche as ben dyseased. But that is contrary vnto the mynde of the auctour / as vnto this place. For he spake before of the nedes of the body / and now he speketh all of the ordre of the maners and behauyour / as well of the soueraynes as subiectes / eche vnto other. He meaneth therfore that ye soueraynes must haue pyte and compassyon vpon ye frayle persones. For in very dede they lesse done offende / than these done that done trespace of purpose / or yet by neglygency / and that all though they do more often offende. For the frayle persone entendeth euer to amende / & so oftentymes wyll faythfully promyse / and yet whan ye occasyon cometh / they fall ouercast by very fraylty / and than ben they bothe sory and ashamed of theyr inconstauncy. They must therfore be receyued vnto mercy. I saye not vnpunysshed / but at ye lest whan they be punysshed / they shold be taken to grace / and (theyr fraylty consydered) to be the more gentylly entreated / and not hagged and tagged by ony furious or hasty maner. And this sentence and exposycyon bryngeth in the fourth lesson for the soueraynes / that is to say / that they shold be pacyent vnto all persones.Texte. This terme / all persones / is referred and applyed vnto these thre maners of persones / whiche (as I touched before) ben the obstynate persones / the ignoraunt or neglygent persones / and the frayle persones / vnto all the soueraynes must be pacyent / and yet shall they do due correccyon / accordyng vnto the defaute. The maner wherof dothe folowe
in the lettre / as ye shall here after

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ Who so kepeth the rome and place of the soueraynes / may do none euyll: it becometh not them to do amysse: notwithstandynge they may somtyme suffre and bere that is done amysse / that by theyr pacyence and mylde behauyour / they may restrayne the hastynes of other persones. For they ben the phisycyons of the soule / and therfore they must agaynst ye passyons of vyces / mynystre the medycynes of vertue. So it belongeth vnto them to serche the maners of the subiectes / & so to dele with eueryche accordynge vnto theyr disposycyon. The lettre.a. l. libet habeat. metuen impona Disciplinā libens adhibeat metuendus imponat. Et {quam}uis vtrū{que} sit necessarium tamen plus a vobis amari appetat {quam} timeri / semper cogitans: deo se pro vobis rationem esse redditurum. That is. Let the soueraynes also be dilygent to gyue discyplyne / and to make reformacyon / and so let them do correccyon / that they be had in reuerent drede. And all though bothe loue & drede be necessary / yet sholde they coueyte and desyre more to be of theyr subiectes beloued than dreded / remembrynge alwaye that for them all / they must rendre accounte / & make answere before our lorde. Saynt Augustyn wyll the soueraynes sholde not be negligent / slowe / or (as many soueraynes ben) lothe to do correccyon / but they sholde do it (as the lettre sayth) libens / with good wyll and fauourably.The origy •… hath here 〈…〉 tuc̄s. died y •… so though soueraynes 〈…〉 doynge of •…
reccyon sho •… euer be dre •…
full. So they may notwithstandynge be had in drede / and the subiectes may well perceyue the correccyon to procede of charite / and for due reformacyon / & not of displeasure / ne for punysshement of the persone And so the appetyte of ye soueraynes shall playnly appere
/ more to be of the subiectes beloued than dreded.

div.head: ¶ Saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ Dyscyplyne (after mayster Cipryane) is an ordynate correccyon / or reformacyon of maners: and an obseruaunce or folowynge of the olde religyous faders. It is therfore necessary / that the soueraynes of relygyon sholde be wyse and well ordred in all discyplyne and religyous behauyour. For than may they iustly and of ryght teche discyplyne and good maner / whan they lyue therafter themselfe / and whan they gyue the example in themselfe of that thynge they wolde haue kepte and exercysed in other.Hebre. xij. I cōmaunde you (sayth the apostle Paule vnto the Hebrewse) that ye perseuer / and do cōtynue in discyplyne / that our lorde god may offre hymselfe vnto you as vnto his childre. And the chylde (we knowe well) is blamed of the fader whan he dothe amysse / or els he sholde not be accounted as a chylde. It is therfore necessary that euery souerayne mynystre vnto the subiectes bothe loue and drede. Drede sholde they mynystre and shewe vnto the proude / hygh mynded / styffe stomacked and rebellyous persones. And vnto the meke and lowly persones / & specially vnto them that with gladde mynde dylygence & deuocyon / done serue god / and kepe theyr obseruaūces and duty / sholde they shewe loue and fauour. And yet all though (as is sayd) bothe loue and d • ede ben necessary / ye soueraynes sholde alway haue appetyte and desyre to be more of theyr subiectes beloued than dreded. For the more the prelate is beloued the better is he herde & obeyed. And that seruyce that is done of loue and with good wyll / doth more please our lorde / than the seruyce that is done for drede. And
therfore our swete lorde & moost gentyll mayster sayd vnto his discyples.Ioan. x. I wyl not (sayth he) call you now seruauntes / but frendes. For our lorde wyll not that we loue hym as a bonde seruaunt dothe his lorde / but rather as a chylde ye fader. And that we kepe his commaūdementes / not for drede of payne / but for the loue of Iustyce. The soueraynes sholde therfore alwaye thynke and remembre they haue a souerayne & iudge ouer themselfe / vnto whome they must gyue a strayte accounte for theyr subiectes / and therfore sholde they be the more dilygent in gyuynge hede vnto theyr rule and charge. For who so dothe well remembre the last ende / wyll doubtles gyue ye more hede and dylygence vnto theyr cure and charge. Wherof the wyse man sayth. Eccli. vi In omnibus tuis / memorare nouissima tua / et ineternum non peccabis. In all that appertayneth vnto the / remembre well thy last ende / and thou shalt not for euer offende god / that is / thou shalt not fynally in conclusyon offende god. The lettre.Texte. Vnde & vos magis obediendo: non solum vestri / sed etiam ipsius miseremini: qui inter vos quanto in loco su{per}iori / tanto in periculo maiori versatur. That is. And therfore sholde you by more lowly obedyence / haue pyte and compassyon / not onely vpon your selfe / but also vpon your soueraynes. For the more hygh place and rome they bere and occupy amonge you / the more ben they in peryll and ieoperdy. ¶ Many persones in religyon set moche by theyr owne labours / and so haue pyte and compassyon vpon themselfe / and stande so moche in theyr owne fauour / that they suppose and thynke veryly theyr meryte and deseruynge is aboue the soueraynes. And therby in iustyfyenge themselfe / they
take the more vpon them / and ben the lesse obedyent. And that wyll not saynt Augustyn in ony wyse / but that rather the subiectes sholde consydre the grete peryll and ieoperdy / wherin the soueraynes ben / that must not onely gyue accoūt for themselfe / but also for all the subiectes. And therfore sholde they be the more meke and lowly vnto theyr souerayne / and haue compassyon vpon theyr labours / although they seme lesse more than vpon theyr owne. Herken now vnto

div.head: Saynt Hugh.
div.p: ¶ They ben surely in grete peryl that ben set in hygh rome of gouernaunce. For the hygher the degree be / the more peryllous is the fall. For more shall be required of them that done receyue moche / than of them that lytell haue receyued. A grete ieoperdy to answere for the lyfe of other persones / and theyr owne bothe And a grete labour and charge / to prouyde for all necessaryes. And so is it bothe ieoperdy / labour & charge vnto the soueraynes to satysfye all partyes / bothe in spirytuall thynges and temporall. And so to cure and hede themselfe / that they be not neglygent of theyr subiectes. And so agayne to thynke vpon them / that they forgete not themselfe. And so to mynystre temporalytees / that in no wyse they waxe colde and dull in spirytualytees.

div.head: ¶ And thus endeth the exposycyon of holy saynt Hugh.
div.p:
¶ The resydue is the lettre / with our poore notes. The lettre.
〈…〉 . l. hec oīa •… um dile
•… tione. Donet igitur deus: vt obseruetis hec oīa tan{quam} spiritualis pulcritudinis amatores / & bono odore Christi de bona cōuersatione fragrantes: non sicut
serui sub lege: sed sicut liberi sub gratia constituti. That is. Almyghty god therfore graūt / that all you may obserue and kepe all these cōmaundementes and iniunccyons / as louers of spirytuall beauty / and by good and holy cōuersacyon smellynge of the good and moost pleasaunt odour & smell of Chryst / not as bonde seruauntes vnder the lawe / but as louynge chyldre vnder the lyberty of grace. Whan saynt Augustyne had ended all the preceptes and cōmaundementes of his rule / and ordred also bothe the soueraynes & subiectes therunto. He now here dothe shewe vnto what ende / and for what cause / or wherfore the dyscyples of this rule sholde perfourme and kepe the same / that is to say / for the loue of god / and vnto the edyfycacyon of the neyghbour / for that is the loue of ye neyghbour. In the begynnynge he shewed how we ben bounde to loue god and our neyghbour. And here he wylleth that for those two causes we sholde vndertake these labours / and kepe these preceptes. And that the discyples of this rule may kepe ye same / he doth fyrst praye sayenge. Our lorde god graunt. For lawes and ordynaunce made / and not kepte / ben all voyde. And than dothe he adde the cause (as we sayd) vnto the merytes of the kepers.In ye or •…
gynall 〈…〉 with lo •… as the •…
uers of •…
rytual •…
auty. & •…
Sayenge / as the louers of spirytuall beauty. Spirytuall beauty is our lorde and his heuenly Ioye. Than who so kepeth ye rule as louers of spirytuall beauty / done kepe it for the loue of god. And than foloweth / and as smellynge / that is / as suche persones that done smell by holy conseruacyon of the odour and smell of Chryst. The odour and smell of Chryst / is his lyfe and behauyour. To smell than of Chryst / is to folowe his example of lyuynge / and
that is the edifycacyon & very loue of the neyghbour. These lawes & statutes than / must (after the mynde of saynt Augustyne) be kepte for the loue of god / and (as we sayd) vnto the edifycacyon of the neyghbour. And not as bonde caytyues done kepe the lawes of theyr lordes / ne yet as the chyldre of Israel kepte the olde lawe for fere and drede of payne / but as louynge chyldre done kepe the cōmaundementes of theyr pyteous and kynde parentes / hauynge theyr fauour & grace. So must ye discyples of this rule take all theyr labours for loue / bycause they stande vnder a double lawe of grace / that is to say / the cōmune lawe of chrystyanite / and also the lawe of perfeccyon / and moost hygh meryte / the lawe of holy relygyon. The lettre. Vt autem vos in libello hoc / tan{quam} in speculo possitis inspicere / ne per obliuionem aliquid negligatur:
〈…〉 . l. negli
•… atis. semel in septimana vobis legatur. That is. And for bycause you in this lytell boke may se and beholde your selfe / as in a myrrour or glasse / let the same boke ones in the weke (lest ony thynge passe you by negligence) be redde amonge you. Lawes can not be kept / except they be knowen / and therfore ben the prelates & prechers bounden to shewe vnto the people the lawe of god / that they may knowe it and kepe it. Soo wyll saynt Augustyn this rule be redde / and so knowen & kepte. And yet that thynge that is well knowen / may soone be forgoten / and so negligently ouerpassed / excepte it be well renewed and grounded in the memory. And therfore he wylleth it be redde euery weke ones / whiche commaundement is full euyll kepte in many places / & in some places no parte therof kepte. For neyther is it redde ones in the weke / ne yet ones
in the yere: ne in some place ony tyme / they neuer herde tell of ony rule / but as other lyued there before they folowe without rule. For they ben clene out of rule. Kepe you the rule I praye you / and let it be redde ones a weke at the leest. And I thynke it may be moche profytable for you to rede this boke euery quarter ones / or thre tymes a yere at the leest in your fratour. For saynt Augustyne dothe assymule this rule vnto a myrrour or glasse / wherin euery persone may se to refourme and redresse / yf ony thynge be amysse.Nota. It is an olde sayenge / ofte rekenynge holdeth longe felawshyp. Than do you reken and make account with our lorde / whan ye loke vpon your owne werkes / & that is to loke in this glasse / where ye may soone se & perceyue wheder ye haue done your duty or no / and than what ye shall do / the lettre sheweth. Vbi autem vos inueneritis ea que scripta sunt facientes: agite domino gratias / bonorū omnium largitori: vbi autem sibi quicun{que} vestrum / vidit aliquid deesse: doleat de preterito / caueat de futuro / orans: vt sibi debitum dimittatur / et in tentationem non inducatur. Amen. That is. And where ye fynde and perceyue ye haue perfourmed & fulfylled all that in this rule ben wryten / gyue you vnto our lorde / the gyuer & rewarder of all goodnes due thankes therfore and prayse. And where ony of you done fynde and perceyue they lacke or wante ony poynt of the same / let them be sory for that is passed / and be ware of that is to come / besechynge our lorde theyr defaute may be forgyuen / and they neuer be brought vnto the consent of synne. Amen. ¶ By redynge this rule / ye may (as in a myrrour or glasse) se and beholde your selfe. And yf ye fynde no thynge amysse
/ but all ye suppose well / ascrybe neuer that in ony wyse vnto your selfe / but vnto our lorde / & thanke his goodnes / and knowlege it came of his specyall grace. And yf ye perceyue ye haue not done your duty be dyscontent with your selfe / and thynke veryly ye wyll ordre your selfe to amende. Than beseche our lord of mercy for all your offences and negligence / and that ye neuer wylfully and by delyberacyon fall vnto the consent of synne. This rekenynge oftentymes made / shall not onely delyuer you from synne / but also obteyne you many synguler graces / and specyall loue of our lorde god and moost swete sauyour Iesu / who euer preserue you all in the dayly encreace of the same by the profyte of religyon. Amen.

div.trailer: ¶ Thus endeth this poore labour of the rule of saynt Augustyn / bothe in latyn and englysshe / with our symple notes / and the profytable exposicyon of ye holy saynt Hugh de sancto Victore by the wretche of Syon Rycharde whytforde.

div.p: ¶ Imprynted at London in Fletestrete / at the sygne of the Sonne / by me Wynkyn de Worde. The yere of our lorde god. M.CCCCC.xxv. the xxviij. daye of Nouember.
